Description: Wheel-made Greek style lamp with glossy black slip. Fragment of half of buff coloured clay greek style oil lamp. It has a circular body, moulded into a dish shape, with a wide raised rim around the edge. There is a hole in the centre with a nozzle shape leading up to the centre. It is glazed black in the centre, with remains of a black glazed handle and traces of thin black conetric circular bands around the top. Buff fabric with pink surface, uncommon quartz, mica and vesicles.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Closest parallels for this form are from Athens (Howland 1958, Type 12A), though fabric does not look convincing for this origin; another Greek or Cypriot origin is possible (Bailey 1975, British Museum Lamps I, Q38 from Athens). Parallels from Sardis (end of the 6th century BC and before a 499 BC destruction layer) and Megara Hyblaea (Bailey 1977, 95). Fabric and decoration resembles that of East Greek Archaic lamps found at Naukratis (British Museum GR 1971,1224.9;GR 1886,0401.1336; GR 1888,0601.147; Bristol Museum H2768). Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals. Princeton.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KC.11) (Phase 1)
